course.@descr: Physical, chemical and biological properties of soils; soil formation, classification, use and conservation. There are no prerequisites for this course, but background in Biology 12, Chemistry 12, and Physics 12 (or first-year university-level) is strongly advised.
A comparative study of pteridophytes, gymnosperms and angiosperms, integrating form, function, and ecology.
course.@prereqs: Either (a) all of BIOL 121, BIOL 180 or (b) all of SCIE 001, BIOL 180.

course.@title: Animal Sheltering and Companion Animal Support Services
course.@descr: History, philosophy, and current practices of animal shelters and companion animal support services, with a focus on emerging issues from a One Health/One Welfare perspective.

Physical principles underlying weather and climates. Thermal, moisture and wind climates from the scale of plants and animals to the globe. Daily weather systems and climate change. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOS (or GEOB) 200, GEOS (or GEOB) 204 or APBI 244.

course.@title: Agroecology I: Introduction to principles and techniques
course.@descr: Biophysical and socioeconomic factors affecting systems management and production in selected agroecosystems.
Principles and practices necessary to understand practical concerns of sustainable food systems.  Students who already present credit for APBI 260 are not permitted to receive credit for APBI 265.
Analysis and interpretation of current issues in applied biology. Topics will vary from year to year.

course.@title: Comparative Cardiovascular, Respiratory and Osmoregulatory Physiology
course.@descr: Cardiovascular, respiratory and osmoregulatory physiology of vertebrates.
course.@prereqs: BIOL 204 and one of BIOL 260, BIOL 361.

course.@descr: Reproductive and digestive physiology, and current technologies applied to these systems in domestic and wild animals.
Case studies will be used to discover how behavioural principles explain complexity in the behaviour of individual animals and contribute to our understanding of animal welfare..
course.@prereqnote: Third-year standing or higher. One of PSYC 100, PSYC 101 or PSYC 102 recommended.

course.@descr: Contemporary use of animals for food production, companionship, recreation and science; social and ethical issues concerning human impacts on animals; animals in human culture; protection of animals by society and the law.
course.@prereqnote: At least third-year standing in any faculty.

course.@title: Animal Welfare and the Ethics of Animal Use
course.@descr: Scientific assessment of animal well-being, ethical concepts applied to animal use, and animal welfare issues arising in agriculture, biomedical research and other areas. Credit will be granted for only one of APBI 315, ANSC 515, or AANB 515.
course.@prereqnote: At least third-year standing in any faculty.

course.@descr: Anatomy, physiology, reproduction, nutrition of the horse; common disease pathology, prevention and treatments; equine behaviour.

course.@title: Welfare and Ethics of using Animals in Science
course.@descr: Historical and current debate, ethical perspectives, governance, and scientific understanding of experiences of animals in research.
Interactions between aquaculture and the environment. Current issues, comparison of systems, species, production methods, environments, and socioeconomics.
course.@prereqs: One of BIOL 230, APBI 260, APBI 265, CONS 330, ENVR 200, ENVR 300.
course.@prereqnote: and third year standing. Or permission of the instructor.

course.@descr: Horticulture theory and methodology in an experiential learning format. Plant identification, seeding, propagation, canopy management, cultivation media, horticultural systems examined in the context of integrated crop management.
Introduction to seed plant taxonomy emphasizing descriptive morphology and identification. Each student will be required to submit a plant collection.
Study of the ecology of plant pathogenic organisms; principles of disease development and control.
A survey of the structure, classification and biology of insects; ecology and life-histories of insects; insect-plant relations.
Importance, identification, dissemination and biology of weeds; preventive, cultural, biological and chemical methods of control.

The diversity of soil organisms (bacteria, protozoa, fungi, animals, plants) in natural and managed ecosystems; roles in primary production, nutrient cycling, decomposition and reclamation; interactions between soil organisms; responses to environmental change.
Mechanisms and regulation of functional processes contributing to the assimilation, transport and utilization of water, mineral nutrients and carbon by plants.
course.@prereqs: BIOL 121 and either (a) CHEM 123 or (b) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113.

course.@title: Agroecology II: Ecology of Agricultural Systems
course.@descr: A variety of ecological processes shape agricultural landscapes. Students will learn the research foundations of applied ecology in agriculture and how to read and critique the scientific literature in this field.
A detailed exploration of biophysical, economic, and social ecosystem sustainability indicators for primary production subsystems.
Research methods including research design, scientific critique, writing proposals and reports, and oral presentation.
course.@prereqnote: Third-year standing in the Applied Biology program or permission of the instructor.

course.@descr: Understanding environmental factors influencing soil-forming processes and their ecological implications. Credit will be granted for only one of SOIL 501 or APBI 401.
Application of fundamental, unifying, soil science principles in sustainable ecosystem management. Credit will be granted for only one of SOIL 502 or APBI 402.

Plant water requirements for production and survival, physiological stress thresholds, soil-plant-atmosphere interactions, structure-function relationships, cutting-edge and traditional monitoring tools, precision agriculture, application for sustainable water management.
Application of physiology and pathology principles to health and disease of domestic animals.
course.@prereqs: BIOL 201 and one of APBI 311, CAPS 301.

course.@descr: Research seminar integrating diverse information to address global animal issues including: animal-source foods and human health, environmental impact of livestock production, trade in exotic animals.

Application of principles and research methods of animal behaviour to practical problems in the care of farm, companion, wild and research animals, and in animal training, and human-wildlife conflict.

Evaluation of humane treatment of individual animals living in the wild and managed within conservation biology. Assessment of attitudes and viewpoints of the role of animal welfare in conservation biology.
course.@prereqnote: Third-year standing or higher. APBI 315 and BIOL 416 or CONS 330 recommended.

course.@descr: Management of fish health in aquaculture; common fish pathogens, epidemiology, prevention, and treatment of diseases.
course.@prereqnote: Third year standing or higher. One of APBI 311, BIOL 204 or BIOL 260. APBI 312 and  APBI 418 strongly recommended.

course.@descr: Perspectives and practices of ecological restoration in diverse ecosystems worldwide.
course.@prereqs: APBI 200 and one of FRST 201, APBI 260, BIOL 230.

course.@descr: Biology and physiology of selected plant-microbe relationships. Impacts of plant-microbe relationships on society.
course.@prereqs: BIOL 200 and one of BIOC 202, BIOC 203, BIOL 201, BIOL 233, BIOL 234, BIOL 260.

course.@descr: Behavioural, population, and community ecology of insects. Interaction between insects and plants and the application of the principals of insect ecology to biological control of insects and weeds.
Development and implementation of multi-disciplinary pest management programs in agricultural crops.

Concepts, principles, and recent discoveries in genome structure and comparative genomics in plants with a focus on economically important plants; applications of genomics approaches to questions in plant genetics, evolution, and ecology.
Ecological, economic and social benefits of incorporating trees into agricultural landscapes. Lectures and groupwork designing agroforestry systems in temperate and tropical contexts.
The relationship between biological diversity and sustainability in food producing agroecosystems; emphasis on ecological similarities between natural ecosystems and managed  agroecosystems.

course.@title: Capstone in Sustainable Agriculture and Food Systems
course.@descr: Integrates classroom and applied learning at the UBC Farm with design project.

course.@title: Advanced Topics in Applied Biology - EXP DSGN, STATS
course.@descr: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in applied biology.

course.@title: Advanced Topics in Applied Biology - POLLINATN ECOLGY
course.@descr: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in applied biology.

course.@title: Advanced Topics in Applied Biology - INDIGNOUS FD SYS
course.@descr: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in applied biology.

course.@title: Advanced Topics in Applied Biology - HU WLDLFE CNFLCT
course.@descr: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in applied biology.

course.@title: Advanced Topics in Applied Biology - HW,D SHELT ANMLS
course.@descr: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in applied biology.

course.@title: Advanced Topics in Applied Biology - TPCS APPL BIOLGY
course.@descr: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in applied biology.

course.@title: Applied Animal Biology Practicum - APBI PRACTICUM
course.@descr: Application of principles and concepts of Applied Animal Biology to experiential learning in the fields of wild, companion, lab, and farm animal welfare and management.
course.@prereqnote: Third-year standing or higher. APBI 314 and/or APBI 315 are recommended.

course.@title: Applied Animal Biology Practicum - APBI PRACTICUM
course.@descr: Application of principles and concepts of Applied Animal Biology to experiential learning in the fields of wild, companion, lab, and farm animal welfare and management.
course.@prereqnote: Third-year standing or higher. APBI 314 and/or APBI 315 are recommended.

course.@descr: Preparation of a comprehensive and analytical review of an approved topic under the supervision of a faculty member. Consultation with a program advisor is required.
Design and execution of an experimental/analytical research project leading to the preparation of a thesis.
course.@prereqnote: Approval of a program advisor; consult before the end of classes in third year.

course.@title: Integrated Physiology for Human Nutrition I
course.@descr: Basic principles in human physiology, including function of the nervous, endocrine, musculoskeletal and digestive systems, integration across systems, maintenance of homeostasis, and application to human nutrition.
course.@prereqs: One of CHEM 11, CHEM 12, CHEM 100, CHEM 110, CHEM 111 and one of BIOL 11, ATPH 12, BIOL 12, BIOL 111.
course.@prereqnote: FNH 160 and 161 together are credit-excluded with BIOL 153 and 155.

course.@title: Integrated Physiology for Human Nutrition II
course.@descr: Basic principles in human physiology, including function of the cardiovascular, immune, respiratory, urinary and reproductive systems, integration across systems, maintenance of homeostasis, and application to human nutrition.
course.@prereqnote: FNH 160 and 161 together are credit-excluded with BIOL 153 and 155.

course.@descr: Chemical and physical properties of foods; issues pertaining to safety, nutritive value and consumer acceptability; government regulations pertaining to food safety, quality and additives; preservation techniques and transformation of agricultural commodities to food products; foods of the future.
course.@prereqnote: At least second year standing required.

course.@descr: Fundamental concepts and principles of human nutrition applied to current nutrition issues.
course.@prereqs: Either (a) all of FNH  160, FNH  161 or (b) one of BIOL 111, BIOL 112, BIOL 153, BIOL 155 or (c) all of KIN  131, KIN  132.

course.@descr: Units and dimensions, mass balance, energy balance, steady state and transient heat flow, fluid handling and measurement.
course.@prereqs: One of PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157, PHYS 158, PHYS 170.

course.@descr: Chemical and physical properties and reactions of food constituents, including water, carbohydrates, proteins, lipids, minerals and vitamins.
course.@prereqs: Either (a) CHEM 201 or (b) CHEM 205;  and either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) CHEM 233.

course.@descr: Principles of and procedures for analysis of the chemical and physical properties of food; proximate analysis; introduction to instrumental analysis; reporting and analysis of data.
course.@prereqs: Either (a) CHEM 201 or (b) CHEM 205;  and either (a) CHEM 203 or (b) CHEM 233.

course.@descr: Introduction to and application of concepts involved in food product formulation and development.
course.@prereqs: One of LFS  252, BIOL 300, EPSE 482, FRST 231, STAT 200.

course.@descr: Preservation of tissue and fluid food systems by selected physical and chemical treatments with emphasis on product-process interactions.
course.@prereqs: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100, PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157, PHYS 158, PHYS 170.

course.@descr: Roles of microorganisms in food production, preservation, spoilage, and foodborne disease; factors affecting growth, survival and inactivation of microorganisms in foods; methods for identifying, enumerating, and eliminating microorganisms in food-production environments.

Laboratory techniques used in food chemistry, microbiology and processing; statistical analysis and presentation of experimental data; scientific report writing. Enrolment restricted to Food Science students.

Laboratory techniques used in food analysis, food processing, sensory science and product development; statistical analysis and presentation of experimental data; scientific report writing. Enrolment restricted to Food Science students.

Principles of viticulture, enology, and wine microbiology and chemistry; marketing, regulation and classification of wines from selected regions of the world; social, economic and health aspects of wine consumption; wine appreciation.

Review of diverse styles of wine with consideration of classic wine-producing areas. Concepts in wine microbiology/chemistry; overview of steps in grape processing for diverse wine styles. Comparison of regulations for Canadian VQA systems with international systems. Wine sensory analysis.
Principles of food preparation based on the physical and chemical properties of food, and experimental and practical applications to food preparation.
course.@prereqs: FNH  200 and either (a) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113 or (b) all of CHEM 121, CHEM 123.

course.@title: Critical Perspectives on Consumer Food Practices
course.@descr: Personal, collective, and policy factors affecting food choices, including perceptions of healthy eating, gender, identity, family structures, and economic, sociocultural, and political forces.
course.@prereqnote: At least third year standing required.

course.@descr: Counselling in dietetics: communication theory and foundational counselling skills.
Fundamentals of energy and macronutrient metabolism.
course.@prereqs: FNH  250 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202.

course.@descr: Vitamin and mineral nutrition and their role in maintaining and promoting health.
course.@prereqs: FNH  250 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202.

course.@descr: Conceptualization and scientific analyses of global problems in food and nutrition; complexities of food habits and malnutrition in various cultures around the world.
The use of dietary, anthropometric, biochemical, and related information for the assessment of nutritional status of individuals and populations.

course.@title: Human Nutrition Over The Life Span
course.@descr: Nutritional requirements and dietary patterns of healthy individuals throughout the life span.

Etiology, pathophysiology, and nutrition therapy for selected diseases and conditions. Topics include metabolism, obesity, eating disorders, diabetes, hypertension, and cardiovascular disease. Restricted to students in year 3 of the dietetics major.
course.@prereqs: All of FNH  350, FNH  370 and one of BIOL 153, BIOL 155.

course.@descr: Introduction to the profession of dietetics in Canada. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major.
course.@prereqnote: Third-year standing in the Dietetics Major.

course.@descr: Process of research; principles and processes in utilizing research. Restricted to students in majors in the FNH program.
course.@prereqs: FNH  250 and either (a) LFS  252 or (b) BIOL 300 or (c) EPSE 482 or (d) FRST 231 or (e) STAT 200.

course.@descr: Functional food concepts related to efficacy and safety; examples of bioactive component-disease relationships; natural health products; approval of functional food and health claims; the importance of clinical studies in support of efficacy for health claims; market determinants of functional foods.

course.@title: Food Laws, Regulations and Quality Assurance
course.@descr: Canadian and international laws governing food composition, grading, quality and safety; hazard analysis critical control points; statistical quality assurance.
course.@prereqs: One of LFS  252, STAT 200, FRST 231, BIOL 300.

course.@descr: Food production plant sanitation, environmental monitoring, global food safety standards, and food plant internal audits.

course.@title: Microbiology of Food and Beverage Fermentation
course.@descr: Fermentation methods, mechanism and microbiology of nonalcoholic fermented foods and alcoholic fermented beverages (beer, cider, sake).
course.@prereqs: One of MICB 201, MICB 202, BIOL 201, BIOL 203, BIOC 203.

course.@descr: Microbial and chemical factors that underlie public health challenges in the food supply chain; prevalence and nature of organisms which cause foodborne diseases; approaches and technologies for improvement of food safety.
course.@prereqs: One of MICB 201, MICB 202, CHEM 233, FNH  313.

course.@descr: Regenerative sustainability and the sustainability nexus; health and environmental impacts of the food industry; environmental performance indicators and management systems; approaches to enhance sustainability in the food industry.

course.@title: Business Concepts in Food, Nutrition, and Health
course.@descr: Introduction to and application of business activities in food, nutrition, and health settings. Credit will only be granted for only one of FNH 415, FOOD 515, or FRE 515.
course.@prereqnote: At least third-year standing in the Faculty of Land and Food Systems.

course.@descr: Outline of the physics and chemistry of interfaces; discussion of the part played by surface effects in technical processes. Credit will be granted for only one of FNH 419 and FOOD 519.
Integrated course designed to illustrate principles of research and product development in the food industry.

Management responsibilities in quantity food production with emphasis on menu planning, purchasing and service. Includes planning and equipping food services. Restricted to students in the Dietetics major. Note: Course registrants are required to possess a Foodsafe II certificate.

course.@title: Nutrient Metabolism and Implications for Health
course.@descr: Integration of nutrient and energy metabolism on a whole-body and individual tissue basis and the implication for health. Emphasis will be on regulation of nutrient metabolism.
course.@prereqnote: and either (a) one of BIOL 153, BIOL 155, CAPS 301 or (b) all of FNH 160 and 161.

course.@descr: Applying nutrition concepts and principles in addressing problems of malnutrition and food insecurity in international settings.  Basics of developing culturally acceptable, sustainable nutrition intervention programs.

Etiology, pathophysiology and nutrition therapy for selected diseases and conditions. Topics include nutrition support, gastrointestinal conditions, surgery, allergies and intolerances. Restricted to students in year 4 of the dietetics major.
Metabolic adaptations, nutrient metabolism, and special issues during pregnancy that may influence the maternal-fetal nutritional supply.

Theory and methods in public health nutrition and health promotion program planning to assess, plan, implement, and evaluate nutrition-related programs for communities and populations. Considers factors affecting behavior and the social determinants of health.

Nutritional needs of athletes, including energy, carbohydrate and protein; hydration; pre-and post-event nutrition, weight management and body composition issues; ergogenic aids; sports-specific guidelines; and special athlete populations.

Etiology, pathophysiology and nutrition therapy for selected diseases and conditions. Topics include neurological disorders, dysphagia, critical care, oncology, hepatobiliary conditions, HIV and renal disease. Restricted to students in year 4 of the dietetics major.
Evidence-based examination of the role of nutrition in the prevention of chronic disease.
Skill development and application for practice education placements and dietetic practice settings.  Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major.
Practice education placements in settings across British Columbia. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major. Pass/Fail.
Practice education placements in settings across British Columbia. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major. Pass/Fail.

course.@title: Advanced Topics in Food, Nutrition, and Health
course.@descr: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in food, nutrition and health.

Directed Studies in Food, Nutrition and Health - DST FOOD,NTR HLT

course.@descr: Credit will be granted for only one of FNH 419 and FOOD 519.

course.@title: Special Topics in Food Science - SP TPS FOOD SCIE
Introductory Topics in Food and Resource Economics
course.@descr: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in food and resource economics. Topics will vary from year to year.

Economic foundations of managerial decision-making. Organization of the firm, demand theory, cost and production, market structure, competitive strategy, welfare-economic foundations of business regulation. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 301, ECON 304, COMM 295.
course.@prereqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102 and MATH 105.

course.@title: Small Business Management in Agri-food Industries
course.@descr: Emphasizes the building of a business plan by exploring topics such as the planning process and financing, marketing and human resource concepts, as applied to an agri-food business, domestically and internationally.

An overview of global food markets including recent trends (e.g., vertical coordination, strategic alliances, multinationals and small firms in niche markets), marketing and trade institutions such as state-trading enterprises and WTO regulations, issues specific to developing nations, and case studies.

course.@title: Empirical Methods for Food and Resource Economics
course.@descr: Introduction to empirical methods with applications for problems in food and resource economics; standard linear regression and methods to address data deficiencies; interpretation of regression results for forecasting and policy analysis.

Characteristics, processes and sources of economic growth, role of agricultural and resource sectors in economic growth, analysis of output and input markets in those sectors, policy failures, tools for empirical analysis of rural markets, growth, and the environment.

Willingness to pay, opportunity costs, externalities, and market failures in natural resource markets; dynamic efficiency; economic applications including mineral, marine, forest, land, water, and biodiversity.

course.@title: Quantitative Methods for Business and Resource Management
course.@descr: Spreadsheet modeling and analysis of business and resource management problems: decision analysis, forecasting, linear programming, simulation modeling, and inventory management.
course.@prereqs: One of ECON 101, ECON 310 and one of LFS  252, BIOL 300, FRST 231, STAT 200.

course.@descr: Roles of government and business in the Canadian economy including effects of public policy on the business environment. Ethical foundations of government, business and personal decision-making.

Microeconomics of consumer decisions and public policy in food contexts; foodborne illness; economic causes and consequences of obesity; sin taxes and prohibitions; information campaigns and advertising; labeling; food waste and ethics.

course.@title: Causal Inference in the Economics of Natural Resource Conservation
course.@descr: Estimating causal relationships in natural resource economics; applied data analysis; econometrics; counterfactual thinking, and applications to the economics of: natural resource conservation, species loss and extraction, protected areas, international trade of wildlife products, and endangered species legislation.
course.@prereqs: One of LFS  252, STAT 200, BIOL 300, ECON 326, COMM 291, FRST 231 and one of ECON 101, ECON 310.

course.@title: Current Issues in Food and Resource Economics

course.@descr: Pass/Fail.

course.@descr: Credit will be granted for only one of FNH 415, FOOD 515 or FRE 515.

course.@descr: Energy water nexus for sustaining ecological goods and services, and food security;  significance in global resource systems.

Issues such as animal models, ethics in animal and human research, statistical methods, and preparation of written reports and manuscripts, etc., will be addressed. Required of all M.Sc. and Ph.D. students in Human Nutrition.

course.@title: Introduction to Land, Food and Community
course.@descr: Orientation to the programs, learning environment and core values of the Faculty of Land and Food Systems; career programs; survey of professional opportunities and requirements.

course.@title: Principles of Microeconomics with Applications to Land and Food Systems
course.@descr: Microeconomic principles focused on private and social decision making related to the use of land, especially in agriculture, forestry, and conservation. Restricted to Faculty of Land and Food Systems students in Land One Option. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 101, LFS 101, ECON 101, or ECON 310

Current issues and cases in Forestry and Land and Food Systems are examined with a focus on integration of first-year subjects and exposure to both Indigenous and Western perspectives.  Restricted to Faculty of Land and Food Systems students in the Land One option.

course.@title: Scholarly Writing and Argumentation in Land and Food Systems
course.@descr: Communicating concepts of food systems and links to human and environmental health through writing, elements of argumentation, evaluating evidence, and searching for and citing references to back up claims; small-class experience. Enrolment limited to LFS students with first year status.

course.@title: Land, Food and Community I: Introduction to Food Systems and Sustainability
course.@descr: Managed systems and concepts of sustainability; economic, ecological and social components; managed landscapes, agri-food systems, and communities; urban and rural systems; the land, food, nutrition and human health continuum.

course.@title: Land, Food, and Community: Quantitative Data Analysis
course.@descr: Introduction to tools needed for data analysis of the economic, ecological, health, and scientific components of land and food systems.
course.@prereqs: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

course.@title: International Field Studies - INTERNL FLD STD
course.@descr: Field studies carried out abroad under staff direction. Participating students are assessed a fee.

course.@title: International Field Studies - INTERNL FLD STD
course.@descr: Field studies carried out abroad under staff direction. Participating students are assessed a fee.

course.@title: First Nations Health and the Traditional Role of Plants
course.@descr: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the First Nations medical systems and medicinal plants. Bridging the traditional with modern sciences. Credit will be granted for only one of LFS 340 or IHHS 301.

course.@title: Land, Food, and Community II: Principles and Practice of Community Food Security
course.@descr: Project-based application of the principles and processes of community food security. Emphasis on developing skills required to address economic, ecological, social, and technological components of managed landscapes, agri-food systems, and communities comprising the land, food, nutrition and health continuum.

Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings.  Work terms are normally four months long.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail.
course.@prereqnote: Must attend all Co-op pre-employment workshops.

course.@descr: Work experience in relevant private and/or public sector settings.  Work terms are normally four months long.  Restricted to students admitted to the Co-op Program in Land and Food Systems. Pass/Fail.
Adopts a journalistic framework to communicate powerful stories and present academic content in new ways through the use of audio and podcasting technology.

Multidisciplinary course in which students, individually and in groups, examine, integrate and apply subject-specific knowledge through the lens of language and the framework of the language sciences, with a focus on themes of real-world importance.
course.@prereqnote: Fourth-year standing or permission of the instructor.

course.@title: Land, Food, and Community III: Leadership in Campus Food System Sustainability
course.@descr: Design, analysis, recommendation or implementation of solutions in response to a food sustainability issue faced by community partners. Emphasis is on professional communication, leadership development, project management and decision-making skills.
Practical application of degree program learning appropriate to students' career goals. Enrolment subject to competition and availability of practicum placements.

Current and emerging issues relevant within the general context of land and water systems, and the significance of professional credibility and exposure.

Urbanization impacts on water resources with a focus on rainwater management, water quality, point and non-point sources of pollution, drinking water and waste water, riparian buffer zones, cumulative effects, and application of beneficial management practices.
Topics in land and water system evaluations and assessing resource development options: monitoring and modelling environmental systems.

course.@descr: History, philosophy, and current practices of animal shelters and companion animal support services, with a focus on emerging issues from a One Health/One Welfare perspective.

Physical principles underlying weather and climates. Thermal, moisture and wind climates from the scale of plants and animals to the globe. Daily weather systems and climate change. Credit will be granted for only one of GEOS (or GEOB) 200, GEOS (or GEOB) 204 or APBI 244.

course.@title: Agroecology I: Introduction to principles and techniques
course.@descr: Biophysical and socioeconomic factors affecting systems management and production in selected agroecosystems.
Principles and practices necessary to understand practical concerns of sustainable food systems.  Students who already present credit for APBI 260 are not permitted to receive credit for APBI 265.

course.@title: Comparative Cardiovascular, Respiratory and Osmoregulatory Physiology
course.@descr: Cardiovascular, respiratory and osmoregulatory physiology of vertebrates.
course.@prereqs: BIOL 204 and one of BIOL 260, BIOL 361.

course.@descr: Reproductive and digestive physiology, and current technologies applied to these systems in domestic and wild animals.
Case studies will be used to discover how behavioural principles explain complexity in the behaviour of individual animals and contribute to our understanding of animal welfare..
course.@prereqnote: Third-year standing or higher. One of PSYC 100, PSYC 101 or PSYC 102 recommended.

course.@descr: Contemporary use of animals for food production, companionship, recreation and science; social and ethical issues concerning human impacts on animals; animals in human culture; protection of animals by society and the law.

course.@title: Animal Welfare and the Ethics of Animal Use
course.@descr: Scientific assessment of animal well-being, ethical concepts applied to animal use, and animal welfare issues arising in agriculture, biomedical research and other areas. Credit will be granted for only one of APBI 315, ANSC 515, or AANB 515.
course.@prereqnote: At least third-year standing in any faculty.

course.@descr: Anatomy, physiology, reproduction, nutrition of the horse; common disease pathology, prevention and treatments; equine behaviour.

course.@title: Welfare and Ethics of using Animals in Science
course.@descr: Historical and current debate, ethical perspectives, governance, and scientific understanding of experiences of animals in research.

Small-scale classical (i.e., non-biotechnological) plant breeding. Hands-on, application-oriented approach to techniques and procedures for managing seed inventories, designing and implementing a simple plant breeding program, and evaluating the impact of selection on breeding populations and desired outcomes.

Horticulture theory and methodology in an experiential learning format. Plant identification, seeding, propagation, canopy management, cultivation media, horticultural systems examined in the context of integrated crop management.
Introduction to seed plant taxonomy emphasizing descriptive morphology and identification. Each student will be required to submit a plant collection.
Study of the ecology of plant pathogenic organisms; principles of disease development and control.
A survey of the structure, classification and biology of insects; ecology and life-histories of insects; insect-plant relations.

The diversity of soil organisms (bacteria, protozoa, fungi, animals, plants) in natural and managed ecosystems; roles in primary production, nutrient cycling, decomposition and reclamation; interactions between soil organisms; responses to environmental change.
Mechanisms and regulation of functional processes contributing to the assimilation, transport and utilization of water, mineral nutrients and carbon by plants.
course.@prereqs: BIOL 121 and either (a) CHEM 123 or (b) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113.

course.@descr: Animals and Plants as Components of Agricultural Ecosystems. A systems approach is used to investigate the functions and interactions of plants and animals in agricultural systems.
A detailed exploration of biophysical, economic, and social ecosystem sustainability indicators for primary production subsystems.
Research methods including research design, scientific critique, writing proposals and reports, and oral presentation.
course.@prereqnote: Third-year standing in the Applied Biology program or permission of the instructor.

course.@descr: Integration of soil physics, chemistry, and biology in understanding essential soil processes.
Application of fundamental, unifying, soil science principles in sustainable ecosystem management.

course.@title: Soil Sampling, Analyses and Data Interpretation
course.@descr: Field and laboratory analytical techniques in the chemical, biological and physical assessment of soils. Credit will be granted for only one of SOIL 503 or APBI 403.

Plant water requirements for production and survival, physiological stress thresholds, soil-plant-atmosphere interactions, structure-function relationships, cutting-edge and traditional monitoring tools, precision agriculture, application for sustainable water management.
Application of physiology and pathology principles to health and disease of domestic animals.
course.@prereqs: BIOL 201 and one of APBI 311, CAPS 301.

course.@descr: Research seminar integrating diverse information to address global animal issues including: animal-source foods and human health, environmental impact of livestock production, trade in exotic animals.

Application of principles and research methods of animal behaviour to practical problems in the care of farm, companion, wild and research animals, and in animal training, and human-wildlife conflict.

Evaluation of humane treatment of individual animals living in the wild and managed within conservation biology. Assessment of attitudes and viewpoints of the role of animal welfare in conservation biology.
course.@prereqnote: Third-year standing or higher. APBI 315 and BIOL 416 or CONS 330 recommended.

course.@descr: Management of fish health in aquaculture; common fish pathogens, epidemiology, prevention, and treatment of diseases.
course.@prereqnote: Third year standing or higher. One of APBI 311, BIOL 204 or BIOL 260. APBI 312 and  APBI 418 strongly recommended.

course.@descr: Ecological principles relevant to restoration of ecosystems are applied to the restoration of several types of ecosystems.
course.@prereqs: APBI 200 and one of FRST 201, APBI 260, BIOL 230.

course.@descr: Biology and physiology of selected plant-microbe relationships. Impacts of plant-microbe relationships on society.
course.@prereqs: BIOL 200 and one of BIOC 202, BIOC 203, BIOL 201, BIOL 233, BIOL 234, BIOL 260.

course.@descr: Behavioural, population, and community ecology of insects. Interaction between insects and plants and the application of the principals of insect ecology to biological control of insects and weeds.
course.@prereqs: Either (a) BIOL 205 or (b) all of BIOL 327, APBI 327.

course.@descr: Development and implementation of multi-disciplinary pest management programs in agricultural crops.

Concepts, principles, and recent discoveries in genome structure and comparative genomics in plants with a focus on economically important plants; applications of genomics approaches to questions in plant genetics, evolution, and ecology.

Grapevine genetics, morphology, and physiology and major biological features of other important berry crops for British Columbia such as blueberry, cranberry, and raspberry. Credit will be granted for only one of APBI 442, APBI 443, or PLNT 542.
course.@prereqs: All of BIOL 112, BIOL 121 and one of BIOL 200, BIOL 201, APBI 210, BIOL 210.

course.@descr: An introduction to the application of knowledge and principles of agroecology and forest ecology to global agroforestry systems. The course includes a one-weekend field trip that requires a supplemental fee.
course.@prereqnote: An undergraduate course in ecology or equivalent.

course.@descr: The relationship between biological diversity and sustainability in food producing agroecosystems; emphasis on ecological similarities between natural ecosystems and managed  agroecosystems.
Insect ecology and evolutionary biology of pests, predators, pollinators and other insect groups in agroecosystems. Application to biodiversity management and sustainable agricultural practices.
course.@prereqs: One of APBI 327, BIOL 327 and one of BIOL 300, GEOG 374, FRST 231, LFS  252, STAT 200.

course.@descr: Introduction to and application of concepts involved in food product formulation and development.

course.@descr: Preservation of tissue and fluid food systems by selected physical and chemical treatments with emphasis on product-process interactions.
course.@prereqs: One of PHYS 12, PHYS 100, PHYS 101, PHYS 106, PHYS 107, PHYS 117, PHYS 131, PHYS 157, PHYS 158, PHYS 170.

course.@descr: Roles of microorganisms in food production, preservation, spoilage, and foodborne disease; factors affecting growth, survival and inactivation of microorganisms in foods; methods for identifying, enumerating, and eliminating microorganisms in food-production environments.

Laboratory techniques used in food chemistry, microbiology and processing; statistical analysis and presentation of experimental data; scientific report writing. Enrolment restricted to Food Science students.

Laboratory techniques used in food analysis, food processing, sensory science and product development; statistical analysis and presentation of experimental data; scientific report writing. Enrolment restricted to Food Science students.

Principles of viticulture, enology, and wine microbiology and chemistry; marketing, regulation and classification of wines from selected regions of the world; social, economic and health aspects of wine consumption; wine appreciation.

Review of diverse styles of wine with consideration of classic wine-producing areas. Concepts in wine microbiology/chemistry; overview of steps in grape processing for diverse wine styles. Comparison of regulations for Canadian VQA systems with international systems. Wine sensory analysis.
Principles of food preparation based on the physical and chemical properties of food, and experimental and practical applications to food preparation.
course.@prereqs: FNH  200 and either (a) all of CHEM 111, CHEM 113 or (b) all of CHEM 121, CHEM 123.

course.@title: Critical Perspectives on Consumer Food Practices
course.@descr: Personal, collective, and policy factors affecting food choices, including perceptions of healthy eating, gender, identity, family structures, and economic, sociocultural, and political forces.
course.@prereqnote: At least third year standing required.

course.@descr: Counselling in dietetics: communication theory and foundational counselling skills.
Fundamentals of energy and macronutrient metabolism.
course.@prereqs: FNH  250 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202.

course.@descr: Vitamin and mineral nutrition and their role in maintaining and promoting health.
course.@prereqs: FNH  250 and one of BIOL 201, BIOC 202.

course.@descr: Conceptualization and scientific analyses of global problems in food and nutrition; complexities of food habits and malnutrition in various cultures around the world.
The use of dietary, anthropometric, biochemical, and related information for the assessment of nutritional status of individuals and populations.

course.@title: Human Nutrition Over The Life Span
course.@descr: Nutritional requirements and dietary patterns of healthy individuals throughout the life span.

Etiology, pathophysiology, and nutrition therapy for selected diseases and conditions. Topics include metabolism, obesity, eating disorders, diabetes, hypertension, and cardiovascular disease. Restricted to students in year 3 of the dietetics major.
course.@prereqs: All of FNH  350, FNH  370 and one of BIOL 153, BIOL 155.

course.@descr: Introduction to the profession of dietetics in Canada. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major.
course.@prereqnote: Third-year standing in the Dietetics Major.

course.@descr: Process of research; principles and processes in utilizing research. Restricted to students in majors in the FNH program.
course.@prereqs: FNH  250 and either (a) LFS  252 or (b) BIOL 300 or (c) EPSE 482 or (d) FRST 231 or (e) STAT 200.

course.@descr: Functional food concepts related to efficacy and safety; examples of bioactive component-disease relationships; natural health products; approval of functional food and health claims; the importance of clinical studies in support of efficacy for health claims; market determinants of functional foods.

course.@title: Food Laws, Regulations and Quality Assurance
course.@descr: Canadian and international laws governing food composition, grading, quality and safety; hazard analysis critical control points; statistical quality assurance.
course.@prereqs: One of LFS  252, STAT 200, FRST 231, BIOL 300.

course.@descr: Food production plant sanitation, environmental monitoring, global food safety standards, and food plant internal audits.

course.@title: Microbiology of Food and Beverage Fermentation
course.@descr: Fermentation methods, mechanism and microbiology of nonalcoholic fermented foods and alcoholic fermented beverages (beer, cider, sake).
course.@prereqs: One of MICB 201, MICB 202, BIOL 201, BIOL 203, BIOC 203.

course.@descr: Microbial and chemical factors that underlie public health challenges in the food supply chain; prevalence and nature of organisms which cause foodborne diseases; approaches and technologies for improvement of food safety.
course.@prereqs: One of MICB 201, MICB 202, CHEM 233, FNH  313.

course.@descr: Regenerative sustainability and the sustainability nexus; health and environmental impacts of the food industry; environmental performance indicators and management systems; approaches to enhance sustainability in the food industry.

course.@title: Business Concepts in Food, Nutrition, and Health
course.@descr: Introduction to and application of business activities in food, nutrition, and health settings. Credit will only be granted for only one of FNH 415, FOOD 515, or FRE 515.
course.@prereqnote: At least third-year standing in the Faculty of Land and Food Systems.

course.@descr: Outline of the physics and chemistry of interfaces; discussion of the part played by surface effects in technical processes. Credit will be granted for only one of FNH 419 and FOOD 519.
Integrated course designed to illustrate principles of research and product development in the food industry.

Management responsibilities in quantity food production with emphasis on menu planning, purchasing and service. Includes planning and equipping food services. Restricted to students in the Dietetics major. Note: Course registrants are required to possess a Foodsafe II certificate.

course.@title: Nutrient Metabolism and Implications for Health
course.@descr: Integration of nutrient and energy metabolism on a whole-body and individual tissue basis and the implication for health. Emphasis will be on regulation of nutrient metabolism.
course.@prereqs: All of FNH  350, BIOC 302 and one of BIOL 153, BIOL 155, CAPS 301.

course.@descr: Applying nutrition concepts and principles in addressing problems of malnutrition and food insecurity in international settings.  Basics of developing culturally acceptable, sustainable nutrition intervention programs.

Etiology, pathophysiology and nutrition therapy for selected diseases and conditions. Topics include nutrition support, gastrointestinal conditions, surgery, allergies and intolerances. Restricted to students in year 4 of the dietetics major.
Metabolic adaptations, nutrient metabolism, and special issues during pregnancy that may influence the maternal-fetal nutritional supply.

Theory and methods in public health nutrition and health promotion program planning to assess, plan, implement, and evaluate nutrition-related programs for communities and populations. Considers factors affecting behavior and the social determinants of health.

Nutritional needs of athletes, including energy, carbohydrate and protein; hydration; pre-and post-event nutrition, weight management and body composition issues; ergogenic aids; sports-specific guidelines; and special athlete populations.

Etiology, pathophysiology and nutrition therapy for selected diseases and conditions. Topics include neurological disorders, dysphagia, critical care, oncology, hepatobiliary conditions, HIV and renal disease. Restricted to students in year 4 of the dietetics major.
Evidence-based examination of the role of nutrition in the prevention of chronic disease.
Skill development and application for practice education placements and dietetic practice settings.  Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major.
Practice education placements in settings across British Columbia. Restricted to students in the Dietetics Major. Pass/Fail.

course.@descr: Analysis and interpretation of current issues in food, nutrition and health.

course.@descr: Credit will be granted for only one of FNH 419 and FOOD 519.
course.@prereqnote: MATH 101 (or equivalent); PHYS 108 (or equivalent); CHEM 154 (or equivalent)

course.@title: Special Topics in Food Science - SP TPS FOOD SCIE

course.@descr: Economic foundations of managerial decision-making. Organization of the firm, demand theory, cost and production, market structure, competitive strategy, welfare-economic foundations of business regulation. Credit may be obtained for only one of ECON 301, ECON 304, COMM 295.
course.@prereqs: All of ECON 101, ECON 102 and MATH 105.

course.@title: Small Business Management in Agri-food Industries
course.@descr: Emphasizes the building of a business plan by exploring topics such as the planning process and financing, marketing and human resource concepts, as applied to an agri-food business, domestically and internationally.

An overview of global food markets including recent trends (e.g., vertical coordination, strategic alliances, multinationals and small firms in niche markets), marketing and trade institutions such as state-trading enterprises and WTO regulations, issues specific to developing nations, and case studies.

course.@title: Empirical Methods for Food and Resource Economics
course.@descr: Introduction to empirical methods with applications for problems in food and resource economics; standard linear regression and methods to address data deficiencies; interpretation of regression results for forecasting and policy analysis.

Characteristics, processes and sources of economic growth, role of agricultural and resource sectors in economic growth, analysis of output and input markets in those sectors, policy failures, tools for empirical analysis of rural markets, growth, and the environment.

Willingness to pay, opportunity costs, externalities, and market failures in natural resource markets; dynamic efficiency; economic applications including mineral, marine, forest, land, water, and biodiversity.

course.@title: Quantitative Methods for Business and Resource Management
course.@descr: Spreadsheet modeling and analysis of business and resource management problems: decision analysis, forecasting, linear programming, simulation modeling, and inventory management.
course.@prereqs: One of ECON 101, ECON 310 and one of LFS  252, BIOL 300, FRST 231, STAT 200.

course.@descr: Roles of government and business in the Canadian economy including effects of public policy on the business environment. Ethical foundations of government, business and personal decision-making.

Microeconomics of consumer decisions and public policy in food contexts; foodborne illness; economic causes and consequences of obesity; sin taxes and prohibitions; information campaigns and advertising; labeling; food waste and ethics.

course.@title: Causal Inference in the Economics of Natural Resource Conservation
course.@descr: Estimating causal relationships in natural resource economics; applied data analysis; econometrics; counterfactual thinking, and applications to the economics of: natural resource conservation, species loss and extraction, protected areas, international trade of wildlife products, and endangered species legislation.
course.@prereqs: One of LFS  252, STAT 200, BIOL 300, ECON 326, COMM 291, FRST 231 and one of ECON 101, ECON 310.

course.@title: Current Issues in Food and Resource Economics

course.@descr: Pass/Fail.

course.@title: Introduction to Land, Food and Community
course.@descr: Orientation to the programs, learning environment and core values of the Faculty of Land and Food Systems; career programs; survey of professional opportunities and requirements.

course.@title: Principles of Microeconomics with Applications to Land and Food Systems
course.@descr: Microeconomic principles focused on private and social decision making related to the use of land, especially in agriculture, forestry, and conservation. Restricted to Faculty of Land and Food Systems students in Land One Option. Credit will be granted for only one of FRST 101, LFS 101, ECON 101, or ECON 310

Current issues and cases in Forestry and Land and Food Systems are examined with a focus on integration of first-year subjects and exposure to both Indigenous and Western perspectives.  Restricted to Faculty of Land and Food Systems students in the Land One option.

course.@title: Scholarly Writing and Argumentation in Land and Food Systems
course.@descr: Communicating concepts of food systems and links to human and environmental health through writing, elements of argumentation, evaluating evidence, and searching for and citing references to back up claims; small-class experience. Enrolment limited to LFS students with first year status.

course.@title: Land, Food and Community I: Introduction to Food Systems and Sustainability
course.@descr: Managed systems and concepts of sustainability; economic, ecological and social components; managed landscapes, agri-food systems, and communities; urban and rural systems; the land, food, nutrition and human health continuum.

course.@title: Land, Food, and Community: Quantitative Data Analysis
course.@descr: Introduction to tools needed for data analysis of the economic, ecological, health, and scientific components of land and food systems.
course.@prereqs: One of MATH 100, MATH 102, MATH 104, MATH 110, MATH 120, MATH 180, MATH 184.

course.@title: International Field Studies - INTERNL FLD STD
course.@descr: Field studies carried out abroad under staff direction. Participating students are assessed a fee.

course.@title: International Field Studies - INTERNL FLD STD

course.@title: First Nations Health and the Traditional Role of Plants
course.@descr: This Interprofessional Health and Human Service (IHHS) course covers the First Nations medical systems and medicinal plants. Bridging the traditional with modern sciences. Credit will be granted for only one of LFS 340 or IHHS 301.

course.@title: Land, Food, and Community II: Principles and Practice of Community Food Security
course.@descr: Project-based application of the principles and processes of community food security. Emphasis on developing skills required to address economic, ecological, social, and technological components of managed landscapes, agri-food systems, and communities comprising the land, food, nutrition and health continuum.

course.@title: Land, Food, and Community III: Leadership in Campus Food System Sustainability
course.@descr: Design, analysis, recommendation or implementation of solutions in response to a food sustainability issue faced by community partners. Emphasis is on professional communication, leadership development, project management and decision-making skills.
